body:
Comment 4: 
From [0]:

"A type declaration binds an identifier, the type name, to a new type that has the same
underlying type as an existing type. The new type is different from the existing type."

IOW In `type t u`, 't' is always the same kind of type[1] as 'u' is. Kind is one of

- Method set
- Boolean type
- Numeric type
- String type
- Array type
- Slice type
- Struct type
- Pointer type
- Function type
- Interface type
- Map type
- Channel type

IMO, the specs are pretty clear and complete about what your issue is.

  [0]: http://golang.org/ref/spec#Type_declarations
  [1]: http://golang.org/ref/spec#Types
